discussion.content: stupid question. fine let's assume it's 2007 and go with the patch then

comments.content: Although this is 2016, the advice is to separate Office and SharePoint. https://sharepoint.stackexchange.com/questions/223487/install-office-2016-on-sharepoint-2016-server#:~:text=We%20always%20recommend%20do%20not,VM%20and%20install%20it%20there.

discussion.content: Should a SharePoint server have office installed though? As part of the hardening process, I would say: No. It doesn't need it at all. Can anyone shed some light on this?
hmmmmmmm.... patch or install -- either is correct but best answer to patch, as it's easier to do (just download the security update). Horrible question though

comments.content: But was it EOL when this question was created though? :P
yep true, both patch or install is correct. But I think one factor is that we know that Office 2007 is already EOL. So needs updating/upgrading to newer versions, I think.

discussion.content: Since the question only mentions that the version is vulnerable, letter D is not a good choice since we're not sure if there is really a patch available to that vulnerability. Better to install a newer version then.

choices.C: Install a newer version of Microsoft Office on the server.
choices.A: Remove Microsoft Office from the server.
choices.B: Document the finding as an exception.
choices.D: Patch Microsoft Office on the server.

choices.C: Employees at the company being acquired will be hostile to the security analyst and may not provide honest answers.
choices.A: Breach of confidentiality and market risks can occur if the potential acquisition is leaked to the press.
choices.B: The parent company is only going through this process to identify and steal the intellectual property of the smaller company.
choices.D: Employees at the company being acquired will be hostile to the security analyst and may not provide honest answers.
choices.E: The industry regulator may decide that the acquisition will result in unfair competitive advantage if the acquisition were to take place.
choices.F: The company being acquired may already be compromised and this could pose a risk to the parent company's assets.

questions.question_text: A security analyst at a large financial institution is evaluating the security posture of a smaller financial company. The analyst is performing the evaluation as part of a due diligence process prior to a potential acquisition. With which of the following threats should the security analyst be MOST concerned? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: When on earth do security analysts deal with industry regulators on market competition??
Most concerned... Information leaking to the market is not as much a risk to the company a e and F are...
A & F are the correct answers

comments.content: Sorry, I made a typo. Answers A and F (not E, which is total bollocks).
I think answers should be A and F too.

discussion.content: This is a bit of an unfair question. The answers are A and E. Key to this is "prior to a potential acquisition". Anyone who has prior knowledge of a potential acquisition, or an acquisition in progress before it is announced to the market, is classed as an "insider" and could be subject to criminal proceedings if they use their inside position to profit from their knowledge. The company will have strict rules about who he can speak to, whether he can deal in shares etc. Answer A has nothing to do with him being a security guy, ANYONE who has prior knowledge (auditors, accountants, execs etc) is subject to this.
It's A and F. F is a no-brainer, and A because it's part of "Corporate Confidential" data.

comments.content:
From "Cybersecurity Analyst Certification Bundle":

Mergers and Acquisitions Data about upcoming mergers and acquisitions of a company is a type of sensitive corporate information whose misuse is most often associated with fraud and conspiracy. If information about an upcoming acquisition were to be prematurely disclosed because of a malicious actor, it could have grave consequences on the finances of both companies.
I also don't understand why a security analyst would be concerned over what potential approvals or disapprovals will take place. The security analyst is mostly concerned about cycbersecurity.

discussion.content: something's gone horribly wrong with this question -- two answers are identical, and only one answer, E, is satisfactory

comments.content: Agree. The security analyst shouldn't even be concerned with the industry regulators in letter E.
A and F. C/D have nothing to do with cybersecurity. What's this analyst supposed to do to determine potential employee hostility? Go in with a polygraph??

discussion.content: C/D & F should be the answer as they are the only security related ones....
A is the correct answer
Agree it's A, the others were discarded.
does not make sense answer "A" for me, i think the answer is "B".

comments.content: SSL is deprecated and replaced by TSL: https://wiki.openssl.org/index.php/SSL_and_TLS_Protocols. The answer is A. LEAP is less secure than PEAP

discussion.content: Answer is C: https://nmap.org/book/osdetect-usage.html
reading data files is no fingerprinting

https://kb.juniper.net/InfoCenter/index?page=content&id=KB22925 OS Fingerprinting refers to the detection of the operating system of an end-host by analyzing packets, which originate from that system. It is used by security professionals and hackers for mapping remote networks and determining which vulnerabilities might be present to exploit.

OS Fingerprinting works only for packets that contain a full-fledged TCP connection; that is the TCP connection should have a SYN, SYN/ACK, and ACK connection.

comments.content: This is fingerprinting, but not OS fingerprinting. No packets have been analyzed. This is just an nmap scan. Since we know it's a hacker conducting this scan, it's same to assume the hacker is trying to penetrate the system.
Agree, i think this is C

discussion.content: is this really A?

choices.E: Enable email services on the device.
choices.A: Disable VPN connectivity on the device.
choices.C: Disable near-field communication on the device.

questions.question_text: A Chief Executive Officer (CEO) wants to implement BYOD in the environment. Which of the following options should the security analyst suggest to protect corporate data on these devices? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: BYOD implies the CEO is NOT buying anything. The users are utilizing their personal mobile devices. That being said, unfortunately all the other answers are crappy. D and F are just less crappy.
I agree with D but why F when not every device supports encryption?

comments.content: question says the CEO wants to implement BYOD. doesn't mention whether any devices have been purchased yet. The analyst can recommend encryption and suggest that the devices support encryption

discussion.content: This question is on the exam.
